headline: Quiche Lorraine
description: This quiche lorraine is made with crisp bacon, Swiss cheese, and onion baked in a buttery, flaky crust with savory egg custard in this classic quiche.

video.description: See how to make an impressive classic with eggs, bacon, and Swiss cheese.
video.name: Quiche Lorraine I

name: Quiche Lorraine

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
Place bacon in a large skillet and cook over medium-high heat, turning occasionally, until evenly browned, about 10 minutes. Drain bacon slices on paper towels, then chop coarsely.
Sprinkle bacon, Swiss cheese, and onion into pastry shell.
Whisk together eggs, cream, salt, sugar, and cayenne pepper in a medium bowl. Pour mixture into pastry shell.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) and continue baking until a knife inserted 1 inch from the edge comes out clean, about 30 minutes. Allow quiche to sit 10 minutes before cutting into wedges.

review.reviewBody: Totally awesome and had no trouble following the recipe Fits perfect no overrun. :)

I made this completely without a crust. Perfect low carb or gluten free breakfast. This has been my go-to recipe and I always use half & half or whipping cream, whatever is on hand. This time I had some Gruyère to use up! Green onions (scallions) work best in my book and I always use the hefty amount of bacon. Precooked-chopped-and crisped up with the onions in the pan! I love how creamy the custard cooks up.

Turned out yummy, however I made a few changes due to what I had on hand. I used chopped green scallions, chopped broccoli, used 1-1/2 cups heavy whipping cream with 1/2 cup water. I also added a heaping tablespoon of flour, 1/2 tsp of salt and black pepper. I combined with all the remaining ingredients, including the bacon. Poured the filling in a 10" crustless glass pie pan. (My husband didn't want a crust.) This came out so soft and delicious. I will definitely make it again.
I used heavy cream because it’s what I had and I added fresh spinach. Otherwise I followed instructions. It was silky and delicious. I will make this again and again.

I had to reduce the amount of egg/cream mixture to fit in the pan without running over. I used 3 eggs and 1 and1/2 cups of cream. I reduced the salt, sugar, and cayenne pepper as well. Turned out perfectly!
My favorite kind of quiche to make. However, all you need is 4 or 5 slices of bacon and it's perfect!

I used this recipe as a guide for the amounts, not because I made Quiche Lorraine, which I will at some point. I made Spinach and Mushroom Quiche, but most of the recipes I read called for 8 eggs, which are 4 too many. The quiche turned out beautifully delicious, thanks to the proper, proportional amounts. This is a great basic quiche recipe, using many different cheeses, vegetables and meats. I used grated gouda in my Spinach and Mushroom Quiche this time, but I have also used grated gruyere. Both were a hit with my family. I'm looking forward to making the Quiche Lorraine soon.

I made this wonderful recipe for a Ladies Lunch. It was a big hit. I actually made it ahead of time and reheated it the day of the lunch. If you fry the bacon and grate the swiss cheese ahead of time, prep time is minimal for the day of.

I always try to find easier ways to make recipes. I used already cooked bacon and dry minced onion and added extra Swiss cheese. Like some people said it came out runny after baking at suggested time, so I cooked it an extra 15 minutes on 300 and it came out perfect. I think you could add a extra egg and I used 2 cups of half and half. I thought it was the best quiche I had ever tasted!
I used two different cheddars for this and one cup half and half, one cup sour cream. Its baking now.
A little bland. Took an extra 20 minutes at 300.

This is the base recipe I use whenever I make quiche. It is wonderful as written tho I would point out you really do need a deep dish pie plate to accommodate the entire amount. I really prefer the flavor of the onions if I saute them first. But having said that we have used a multitude of different vegetables and meats with great success. Chopped ham, crispy bacon, steamed broccoli, spinach etc all good! Love the pie crust from the freezer case at Trader Joes to make this come together even quicker. I have no tolerance for hot/spicy foods at all but the pop of cayenne in this recipe is perfect and distinctive and I believe is part of this recipe's stand out above the rest success! Sometimes we serve it with a little hollandaise and toasted english muffins on the side YUM
Great recipe. I have made this many times. Easy to adjust if you don't have the exact ingredients. I omit the onion and bacon.
HELLO CHEF ,HERE I am with a great good news for you about the khal.com a cooking land for cooking kings and queens like you.??
I liked it.. the heat (cayenne pepper) was just enough. Next time will try adding nutmeg instead of the cayenne.

First of all it takes more more time to prepare than 15 mins! It took me an hour and a half at least before it went in the oven. I baked frozen pie crust, sauted the onions to get some of the moisture out of them, cubed and fried a ham steak in a little butter and teaspoon brown sugar, grated all the cheese - gruyere and old white cheddar -and finally I didn't have any heavy cream so I had to substitute it with sour cream, melted butter and milk. I made a mistake by not dredging the grated cheese in flour. It turned into big clumps when i put it in the egg mixture. Think I would sprinkle the cheese on last over the egg mixture in the crust next time. 
I put the pies onto a baking tray which was good because it spilt quite a lot because I over filled them.
It turned out delicious so I'm glad I made two of them. I doubled the recipe and added an extra egg and a tablespoon of cornstarch just for safety.

Turned out wonderful! I cheated and used precooked bacon to speed up prep time and since I couldn't find pre-shredded swiss cheese anywhere, I used a 6-oz pack of sliced swiss and just chopped up the slices into small chunks. I also skipped the cayenne pepper and sprinkled in Tajin seasoning instead, made it perfect. This is my go-to quiche recipe from now on.

I love this recipe! It was soooo delicious! I will 10/10 make it again because of how easy it is and how little I need to make it. I switched the bacon out with ham because I didn't have bacon and it was still amazing!
Delicious. I have changed the cheese I use and sometimes add ham or sausage instead of bacon. Works for so many different quiches,

A delicious, easy and forgiving recipe! Solely because it's what I had on hand, I used duck eggs instead of chicken eggs, and half-and-half instead of light cream, and it turned out beautifully! I might consider browning the onions in the bacon fat next time.

This is a fantastic recipe! I only made one change because of prior reviews. I reduced the light cream from 2 cups to 1.5 cups. It is definitely not too much for a 9" pie pan. It's perfect. I warmed up the leftovers (there's only two of us!) in the microwave and it was super delicious! Will make this often.

Too much bacon!
I have never said that in my life, ever. But in this odd instance, I highly recommend 6-8 strips of bacon. Probably 6 if you want to appreciate a more balanced flavor profile. I would like to taste the egg and cheese and not overwhelm with bacon. Otherwise the recipe cooked up in a very lovely texture and appearance. 
I will use this recipe again...with bacon restraint
This recipe would be better in a 10 inch pie crust.

This was really good! The only change I made was to cut back the cream to 1.5 cups as other reviewers suggested. That made it the perfect amount of filling with the other amounts as in the recipe. I also followed the baking instructions and had no issue with runniness.
I did mine with turkey bacon and added green bell pepper. To stop it from being too runny I simply sprinkled it with a little flour in the egg mixture. It turned out perfect

Made this twice now. The first time as written except no onions. The second time I added some green asparagus I sauteed in the bacon grease and used mozzarella instead of Swiss cheese because I didn't have any. Both times I prebaked the crust about 5 minutes.
Excellent recipe!

This was amazing but I made many changes. I only used 1 cup of half and half and 1 1/4 cups shredded swiss and 3/4 cup shredded low fat sharp cheddar. I used 1 Tablespoon butter to saute the onion until soft then added 2 cloves minced garlic to the pan for another two minutes and then allowed the onion garlic mixture to cool slightly. I eliminated the sugar. I added the bacon, both cheeses and onion/garlic mixture to the egg/half and half/salt/cayenne pepper mixture and poured into the pie crust. I cooked at an even 375 degrees for 45 minutes or until set.

Based on prior reviews thought this would be great. Followed the recipe exactly and very runny and very salty. Cooked low, 300, an extra 20 min and still did not solidify. Add more egg, decrease cream, use low sodium bacon. Will try again but a fail as written.
On,y change was due to unavailability of Swiss cheese, so substituted an Italian blend. It was yummy,

Very yummy! I did a little variation tho-used Loranne cheese from the deli-more swissy flavor. I also put the chopped onion in the microwave with seran wrap covering it for about 1 min so they onions were translucent. I cooked the quiche for 20 min at 425 then dropped it to 350 for about 45 min. It always takes longer than you'd think. when I take it out of oven, I drape more swiss on top so it slowly melts as it is cooling. Oh, and I use whole milk instead of cream. Sometimes I add a tablespoon or two of cottage cheese or sour cream. QUiche is a great recipe to thro all sorts of things in it!
This dish turned out perfect!

Here’s a concept...I made EXACTLY AS WRITTEN :) and it was wonderful! Light, not dense at all. Love this recipe. I’ve also made with diced ham...just as good. I was able to fit all into a 9” DEEP dish pie crust. It was to the top but it fit.

This quiche turned out great! I used 1 1/2 cups of cream after reading other reviews. I had leftover frozen easy pie crust dough which I used. It turned out great. I had to cook for 15 minutes longer than recommended but I blame this on my putting the glass pie pan on top of a metal cookie sheet in the oven. After removing the cookie sheet, the crust took the extra 15 min. to cook.
I added some fresh ground nutmeg!
Made it by the book. I already made it again. Delicious!
Added chopped spinach and it was the best. I have had request to make it by many friends and co-workers.

Great recipe. I read some of the other reviews and am confused... I have made this recipe many times and it turns out perfectly.... It all fits in the pie plate and sets up well. Be sure to let set for 10 to 15 minutes after taking out of the oven to allow the cheese to set... Also, I would expect it to be runny if adding mushrooms and / or spinach both are mostly water.
I added one clove garlic (minced)
We've made this countless times, wonderful.
Delicious, especially with that kick of cayenne.
This was great! I did everything as written, only I cut the light cream to about 1 and 1/4 cups.

Excellent with modifications suggested by other reviewers. Also it is enough for close to 2 pie crusts (store bought).
Doubled the onions and sauteed with garlic. 
Doubled the cheese.
Used 14 strips of bacon instead of 12.
Required a smidge more cream. 
I make it frequently and freeze one fully baked quiche for later.
I've made this twice and it's come out good both times. I reduced the cream by half and also added a quarter cup of chopped red bell pepper - mainly for the color and a little bit of texture.
Delish!
Quiche turned out watery

I used heavy cream. I agree with some of the others. Too much for 1 pie crust. However, used deep dish crust and had to throw out a little bit of mix. Also had to cook it for an extra 1/2 hour. Still, delicious.
Love it! Simple easy recipe. A keeper!
The best quiche to make for my family who doesn’t like spinach or mushrooms.

Thanks for the recipe Laundrie - my Quiche Lorraine turned out great!! I did make a few changes: as previously suggested I only used 1 1/2 c. of half-n-half (it would have overflowed if I used 2 c.), baked for 5-10 mins. longer, and I used more cheese and onion. I also added 2 pinches of dry mustard to the wet mix. The quiche consistency was a perfect creamy custard mixture. The only thing I might do different next time is to mix the ingredients in the egg mix before pouring, that way it's part of the batter (my husband didn't like it only on the bottom). This is also a great base for other types of quiches. Thanks again for sharing!
followed the recipe (altho I lightly sautéed onions instead of putting them in dish raw) and it was the best basic quiche I have had over the years!!! family loved it also so it will be made often!!
amount of cream works for making 2 at once
This is excellent! The whole family loved it, even the picky eaters. I did have to cook it an extra few minutes.
Loved it. Needed more cooking time but came out great.

Absolutely delicious ??
I just couldn't help myself and added about 1 cup of fresh minced spinach to the pie. I love my veggies.

Best quiche I ever made, thanks to this recipe and getting the correct egg to cream ratio to make a creamy egg custard, instead of scrambled egg texture.

One thing I did differently was I added the bacon, cheese, and onion and baked with the shell for about 10 minutes; then I added the egg mixture.

The result was delicious, and the custard was pronounced.

Thank you.
I made this gluten free with a gluten free crust. Also used leftover ham rather than bacon. It got raves from the family, regardless of whether they have celiac or not. Will definitely make it again.

I made this today and made my own crust. I baked it exactly as directed and let it sit 10 minutes as directed before serving. Even the first slice came out perfectly and my husband loved it. This is definitely going to be my go recipe for quiche!

delicious!!!! after reading a few reviews the only thing I did was add another egg, farm fresh brown eggs from my own chickens and I also added maybe a 1/4 cup or a tad over of gruyere cheese. Came out delicious!!!!!
It was delicious. I substituted the bacon for smoked ham.

Like many who have commented, I had leftover mixture. This could work in a deep-dish crust. I also found it was not done in the amount of time suggested and needed to be firmer. I used half and half so I don't know how much that affected the outcome. Overall, it was still delicious. I will make again with some of the adjustments others have suggested.
I found this quiche to tast better the second day. It developed more flavour. Will use again with modifications.
add 1/2 cup Parmesan cheese
I changed some of these ingredients to the leftovers I had in the fridge and it still came out spectacular! Easy meal and quick, easy on the pallet!
I added sauteed peppers with the bacon, and added some ground mustard to egg/milk mixture. Yummy!

Simple enough recipe and I'll definitely make it again. I followed the advice and only used 1 1/2 cups of light cream. Since I over shredded the large block of Swiss cheese, I ended up putting in a rounded cup but I'm sure it didn't make a difference. I also stuck the pie crust in the over for 6 minutes before adding everything in. As others have said, there is no way another 1/2 cup of milk could have fit into the pie crust, especially since I think it could have used more bacon. I also followed the advise and sautéed the onion with the bacon grease and since I don't have cayenne pepper, I used crushed garlic which I sautéed with the onion as well. It turned out great for the brunch and there wasn't any of it left.

Very disappointed. I followed the above recipe precisely, but the saltiness made it inedible by me and my guests. I even made another using spinach instead of bacon, and it was inedible as well. I clearly remember adding the 3/4 teaspoon salt that the recipe called for.
Less bacon, more cheese, and a. lot more onion made this perfect.

Super tasty! I used Pillsbury crust and baked t before adding the mixture in. I used 1.5 cups of 10% cream and cooked it at 300 degrees for 50 minutes rather than 30 as the recipe suggests. Would make again!

The smell is the best thing I have ever smelt! I used a store bought crust and pre baked it. I quadrupled the recipe (I’m feeding a lot of people) and I only had five cups of cream instead of the recommended eight and it turned out well. It needed like 30 extra minutes but the top is nice and crispy. I absolutely love this recipe!!!
This was delicious. It is fine to substitute half and half for light cream.
I love this recipe in particular because it has the split baking temps. The filling is more creamy and doesn’t break like scrambled eggs.

I only used 1 1/2 cups of cream as well, used 10 slices of bacon and added 1/3 cup of good medium cheddar to 1 1/4 cups of Swiss cheese and a pinch or two of nutmeg. It was delicious. It was a perfect consistency and got rave reviews.

Awesome recipe! Made a few changes, sautéed the bacon drained most of the grease and then sautéed the onions with the bacon and the remaining bacon grease. Used 1 3/4 cup heavy cream and 1/2 cup milk, added 1/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese, did not add sugar. Started layering the bacon/onion with the cheese, made four layers. It was amazing, our daughter who cannot stands eggs liked it. High recommended.

I wish I read the reviews first. I followed the recipe exactly and the crust started to burn when I had the oven at 425 even before 15 minutes. When I took it out after another 30 minutes, it was mushy! I also thought the flavor of raw onions was too strong and I do love onions.! It just wasn't right for this dish. Onions were overpowering. IF I were to make it again, I wouldn't cook it at 425 for 15 minutes. I would use less cream and I would sautee the onions before additing to the quiche and I would cook it longer! Read the suggestions of the satisfied users before making this!

I followed the recipe but used leftover ham and used half heavy cream and milk because that's what I had on hand. I did saute the onions beforehand in butter. I found this recipe creamy and delicious and would make again. While I understand the preference for a firmer quiche, this was a special treat and the creaminess made it special for us. Would make again!
Made exactly as is. The best quiche I’ve tasted. I bake then cut it into slices and freeze it. When I want a quiche I take 1 slice out of the freezer heat it up and have it with a salad. Delicious
Good basic recipe but the 2 cups of half and half is way too much!. I use a deep dish crust and I add just one cup cream and 5 eggs instead of 4, comes out perfect every time!.

This recipe made the lightest quiche. Guest who ate it asked if it was made with egg whites. I mixed 1:1 ration of half and half and heavy whipping cream because I couldn't find light cream. I also used pancetta instead of bacon. Delicious!

Great recipe...I made one quiche with the ingredients listed and a second with Cougar Gold cheese and WSU Coug sausage (quiche laCoug). Both were a hit with my football crowd the morning after a win by the Cougs.

I scaled this down to 3 servings, using a small, round casserole dish that I lightly sprayed with cooking spray. I made this crustless (like a lot of quiches I make), and it came out great. I saw comments about the onions being crunchy, so I sauteed them in 1 tblsp of butter for about 5 min. I layered half bacon, half cheese and half onions, and repeated. I wanted to use up what I had on hand, using micro-bacon and 1/2 regular milk and 1/2 heavy whipping cream. Cooking times worked very well. I tried some after 10 min (couldn't wait!); a little loose at that time. Delicious tasting Quiche Lorraine; just how I remember it. Once it sets up in the fridge, the texture will surely improve. Thanks - great recipe! UPDATE 10/26/17: My hunch was right. Much better texture the next day, just delicious!
Cooking time takes longer center was not firm till 1 hour at 350

I sauteed ham, onion and green onion; layered it on top of the crust; added (de)frozen mixed vegetables and spinach; and after pouring on the egg mixture (made with sour cream), decorated the top with cherry tomatoes that were drained earlier. I forgot about the cheese--but it was good!
The method of using a hotter oven at first and then lowering the temperature seems to make for a crunchier crust.
Perfect recipe! I will be making this again this weekend!

Very nice recipe, I always read other reviews where some ppl do adjustments I had a 10 inches store bought crust,I bought bacon bits and used green onions instead of regular onions,I also added spinach I cut the cream to 1 cup as some reviews suggested i follow the rest of the recipe it came out nice i thought it was actually dry not runny at all next time I might add more cream,and make sure you cover the edges with foil cuz it came out too dark lol but overall it's a keeper!

Awesome recipe, however I don't see how 2 cups of cream will fit in any deep dish pie crust. 1.5 cups with 4 eggs fit perfectly and was delicious! I used 1.5 cups half and half, because I could not find light cream. I also used gruyere cheese since that's traditional, and I cooked the onions in the bacon grease. I also used a dash of nutmeg instead of the cayenne pepper. I used a deep dish frozen pie crust, and cooked the quiche 15 minutes on the higher heat and then 45 minutes on 350. It turned out perfectly and the crust did not brown too much. I did not have to cover the crust edges with foil! With these changes the recipe is to die for, so I took away 1 star since I had to make changes.
I made this recipe exactly as directed and it turned out beautifully and was delicious! Will definitely make it again.
Used a big pie pan. Doubled the eggs, cream, and added spinach that sorely needed to be used.
Even my 9 and 7 year old daughters loved this. It was amazing!
I also cut down the light cream to 1 1/2 cups and omitted the sugar. It was flawless. Wonderful texture! My new favorite quiche lorraine recipe.
Perfect in every way. I had no problem fitting it into a 9in deep dish pie shell. I did leave out the sugar and I didn't think it would add anything. I've made it twice in the past 2 weeks. Yum

A family favorite--we have made this recipe many times. I pre-chop the bacon while frozen and it cooks up nicely. We have tried ham, spinach and other leftover goodies as well. Wonderful reheated too.

I have no idea what people are talking about with there being too much filling or it not cooking firmly enough. I made this just as the recipe states, except for sautéing the onions and had absolutely zero issue. It was perfect.
I added mushrooms, shallots , compte instead of Swiss and 1 teaspoon catsup instead of the sugar. Amazing! My husband said he wants this once a week for dinner.
Definitely a do-over recipe. Quiche was light and fluffy. I always make my quiche 'crustless' to save on calories, as I'm not a big fan of piecrust. Great recipe. Thanks!

I liked this quiche okay except I think the crust should have been cooked before adding the egg mixture, to avoid the bottom becoming mushy, as it did with this one. Followed the recipe exactly as written. This quiche is a bit creamier than other quiches I've made.

This recipe, as is, makes an extremely runny quiche that is almost inedible. 2 cups of cream is too much. I would add an egg, add an extra 1/2 C of cheese and decrease the cream by at least 1/2 C (maybe even by one whole cup).
Family loved it!
Husband said it was perhaps the best quiche he's ever had. So, I'll definitely make this one again!
